body_html:
@apaszke Thanks for you quick response, and totally agree with you about the Python overhead. We tried to build a lightweight layer-by-layer profiler as a pytorch third-patry package. This profiler is very easy to enable or disable. We use the PyTorch hook function in module and you could get a layer-by-layer profiling result for both forward and backward.
To do this profiling, we have to make a little code change in backward hook.(see readme).
body_text:
@apaszke Thanks for you quick response, and totally agree with you about the Python overhead. We tried to build a lightweight layer-by-layer profiler as a pytorch third-patry package. This profiler is very easy to enable or disable. We use the PyTorch hook function in module and you could get a layer-by-layer profiling result for both forward and backward.
To do this profiling, we have to make a little code change in backward hook.(see readme).
body:
@apaszke Thanks for you quick response, and totally agree with you about the Python overhead. We tried to build [a lightweight layer-by-layer profiler ](https://github.com/zhuwenxi/pytorch-profiling-tool)as a pytorch third-patry package. This profiler is very easy to enable or disable. We use the PyTorch hook function in module and you could get a layer-by-layer profiling result for both forward and backward. 
To do this profiling, we have to make a little code change in backward hook.(see readme).
